trans-unit.source: Microservices hosted in Docker
trans-unit.target: Microservices hosted in Docker

trans-unit.source: Microservices hosted in Docker
trans-unit.target: Microservices hosted in Docker

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Microservices hosted in Docker
trans-unit.target: Microservices hosted in Docker

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: This tutorial details the tasks necessary to build and deploy an ASP.NET Core microservice in a Docker container.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial details the tasks necessary to build and deploy an ASP.NET Core microservice in a Docker container.

trans-unit.source: During the course of this tutorial, you'll learn:
trans-unit.target: During the course of this tutorial, you'll learn:

trans-unit.source: How to generate an ASP.NET Core application using Yeoman
trans-unit.target: How to generate an ASP.NET Core application using Yeoman

trans-unit.source: How to create a development Docker environment
trans-unit.target: How to create a development Docker environment

trans-unit.source: How to build a Docker image based on an existing image.
trans-unit.target: How to build a Docker image based on an existing image.

trans-unit.source: How to deploy your service into a Docker container.
trans-unit.target: How to deploy your service into a Docker container.

trans-unit.source: Along the way, you'll also see some C# language features:
trans-unit.target: Along the way, you'll also see some C# language features:

trans-unit.source: How to convert C# objects into JSON payloads.
trans-unit.target: How to convert C# objects into JSON payloads.

trans-unit.source: How to build immutable Data Transfer Objects
trans-unit.target: How to build immutable Data Transfer Objects

trans-unit.source: How to process incoming HTTP Requests and generate the HTTP Response
trans-unit.target: How to process incoming HTTP Requests and generate the HTTP Response

trans-unit.source: How to work with nullable value types
trans-unit.target: How to work with nullable value types

trans-unit.source: Why Docker?
trans-unit.target: Why Docker?

trans-unit.source: Docker makes it easy to create standard machine images to host your services in a data center, or the public cloud.
trans-unit.target: Docker makes it easy to create standard machine images to host your services in a data center, or the public cloud.

trans-unit.source: Docker enables you to configure the image, and replicate it as needed to scale the installation of your application.
trans-unit.target: Docker enables you to configure the image, and replicate it as needed to scale the installation of your application.

trans-unit.source: All the code in this tutorial will work in any .NET Core environment.
trans-unit.target: All the code in this tutorial will work in any .NET Core environment.

trans-unit.source: The additional tasks for a Docker installation will work for an ASP.NET Core application.
trans-unit.target: The additional tasks for a Docker installation will work for an ASP.NET Core application.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: You’ll need to setup your machine to run .NET core.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need to setup your machine to run .NET core.

trans-unit.source: You can find the installation instructions on the [.NET Core](https://www.microsoft.com/net/core) page.
trans-unit.target: You can find the installation instructions on the [.NET Core](https://www.microsoft.com/net/core) page.

trans-unit.source: You can run this application on Windows, Ubuntu Linux, macOS or in a Docker container.
trans-unit.target: You can run this application on Windows, Ubuntu Linux, macOS or in a Docker container.

trans-unit.source: You’ll need to install your favorite code editor.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need to install your favorite code editor.

trans-unit.source: The descriptions below use [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/) which is an open source, cross platform editor.
trans-unit.target: The descriptions below use [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/) which is an open source, cross platform editor.

trans-unit.source: However, you can use whatever tools you are comfortable with.
trans-unit.target: However, you can use whatever tools you are comfortable with.

trans-unit.source: You'll also need to install the Docker engine.
trans-unit.target: You'll also need to install the Docker engine.

trans-unit.source: See the [Docker Installation page](https://docs.docker.com/engine/installation/) for instructions.
trans-unit.target: See the [Docker Installation page](https://docs.docker.com/engine/installation/) for instructions.

trans-unit.source: Docker can be installed in many Linux distributions, macOS, or Windows.
trans-unit.target: Docker can be installed in many Linux distributions, macOS, or Windows.

trans-unit.source: The page referenced above contains links to each of the available installations.
trans-unit.target: The page referenced above contains links to each of the available installations.

trans-unit.source: You'll also need to install a number of command line tools that support ASP.NET core development.
trans-unit.target: You'll also need to install a number of command line tools that support ASP.NET core development.

trans-unit.source: The command line templates use Yeoman, Bower, Grunt, and Gulp.
trans-unit.target: The command line templates use Yeoman, Bower, Grunt, and Gulp.

trans-unit.source: You may already have many of these tools, but if not, run the following command in your favorite shell:
trans-unit.target: You may already have many of these tools, but if not, run the following command in your favorite shell:

trans-unit.source: This instructs the node package manager (npm) to install the needed tools.
trans-unit.target: This instructs the node package manager (npm) to install the needed tools.

trans-unit.source: The '-g' option indicates that it is a global install, and those tools are available system wide.
trans-unit.target: The '-g' option indicates that it is a global install, and those tools are available system wide.

trans-unit.source: (A local install scopes the package to a single project).
trans-unit.target: (A local install scopes the package to a single project).

trans-unit.source: Once you've installed those core tools, you need to install the yeoman asp.net template generators:
trans-unit.target: Once you've installed those core tools, you need to install the yeoman asp.net template generators:

trans-unit.source: Create the Application
trans-unit.target: Create the Application

trans-unit.source: Now that you've installed all the tools, create a new asp.net core application.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've installed all the tools, create a new asp.net core application.

trans-unit.source: To use the command line generator, execute the following yeoman command in your favorite shell:
trans-unit.target: To use the command line generator, execute the following yeoman command in your favorite shell:

trans-unit.source: This command prompts you to select what Type of application you want to create.
trans-unit.target: This command prompts you to select what Type of application you want to create.

trans-unit.source: For this microservice, you want the simplest, most lightweight web application possible, so select 'Empty Web Application'.
trans-unit.target: For this microservice, you want the simplest, most lightweight web application possible, so select 'Empty Web Application'.

trans-unit.source: The template will prompt you for a name.
trans-unit.target: The template will prompt you for a name.

trans-unit.source: Select 'WeatherMicroservice'.
trans-unit.target: Select 'WeatherMicroservice'.

trans-unit.source: The template creates eight files for you:
trans-unit.target: The template creates eight files for you:

trans-unit.source: A .gitignore, customized for asp.net core applications.
trans-unit.target: A .gitignore, customized for asp.net core applications.

trans-unit.source: A Startup.cs file.
trans-unit.target: A Startup.cs file.

trans-unit.source: This contains the basis of the application.
trans-unit.target: This contains the basis of the application.

trans-unit.source: A Program.cs file.
trans-unit.target: A Program.cs file.

trans-unit.source: This contains the entry point of the application.
trans-unit.target: This contains the entry point of the application.

trans-unit.source: A project.json file.
trans-unit.target: A project.json file.

trans-unit.source: This is the build file for the application.
trans-unit.target: This is the build file for the application.

trans-unit.source: A Dockerfile.
trans-unit.target: A Dockerfile.

trans-unit.source: This script creates a Docker image for the application.
trans-unit.target: This script creates a Docker image for the application.

trans-unit.source: A README.md.
trans-unit.target: A README.md.

trans-unit.source: This contains links to other asp.net core resources.
trans-unit.target: This contains links to other asp.net core resources.

trans-unit.source: A web.config file.
trans-unit.target: A web.config file.

trans-unit.source: This contains basic configuration information.
trans-unit.target: This contains basic configuration information.

trans-unit.source: A Properties/launchSettings.json file.
trans-unit.target: A Properties/launchSettings.json file.

trans-unit.source: This contains debugging settings used by IDEs.
trans-unit.target: This contains debugging settings used by IDEs.

trans-unit.source: Now you can run the template generated application.
trans-unit.target: Now you can run the template generated application.

trans-unit.source: That's done using a series of tools from the command line.
trans-unit.target: That's done using a series of tools from the command line.

trans-unit.source: The `dotnet` command runs the tools necessary for .NET development.
trans-unit.target: The `dotnet` command runs the tools necessary for .NET development.

trans-unit.source: Each verb executes a different command
trans-unit.target: Each verb executes a different command

trans-unit.source: The first step is to restore all the dependencies:
trans-unit.target: The first step is to restore all the dependencies:

trans-unit.source: Dotnet restore uses the NuGet package manager to install all the necessary packages into the application directory.
trans-unit.target: Dotnet restore uses the NuGet package manager to install all the necessary packages into the application directory.

trans-unit.source: It also generates a project.json.lock file.
trans-unit.target: It also generates a project.json.lock file.

trans-unit.source: This file contains information about each package that is referenced.
trans-unit.target: This file contains information about each package that is referenced.

trans-unit.source: After restoring all the dependencies, you build the application:
trans-unit.target: After restoring all the dependencies, you build the application:

trans-unit.source: And once you build the application, you run it from the command line:
trans-unit.target: And once you build the application, you run it from the command line:

trans-unit.source: The default configuration listens to http://localhost:5000.
trans-unit.target: The default configuration listens to http://localhost:5000.

trans-unit.source: You can open a browser and navigate to that page and see a "Hello World!"
trans-unit.target: You can open a browser and navigate to that page and see a "Hello World!"

trans-unit.source: message.
trans-unit.target: message.

trans-unit.source: Anatomy of an ASP.NET Core application
trans-unit.target: Anatomy of an ASP.NET Core application

trans-unit.source: Now that you've built the application, let's look at how this functionality is implemented.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've built the application, let's look at how this functionality is implemented.

trans-unit.source: There are two of the generated files that are particularly interesting at this point: project.json and Startup.cs.
trans-unit.target: There are two of the generated files that are particularly interesting at this point: project.json and Startup.cs.

trans-unit.source: Project.json contains information about the project.
trans-unit.target: Project.json contains information about the project.

trans-unit.source: The two nodes you'll often work with are 'dependencies' and 'frameworks'.
trans-unit.target: The two nodes you'll often work with are 'dependencies' and 'frameworks'.

trans-unit.source: The dependencies node lists all the packages that are needed for this application.
trans-unit.target: The dependencies node lists all the packages that are needed for this application.

trans-unit.source: At the moment, this is a small node, needing only the packages that run the web server.
trans-unit.target: At the moment, this is a small node, needing only the packages that run the web server.

trans-unit.source: The 'frameworks' node specifies the versions and configurations of the .NET framework that will run this application.
trans-unit.target: The 'frameworks' node specifies the versions and configurations of the .NET framework that will run this application.

trans-unit.source: The application is implemented in Startup.cs.
trans-unit.target: The application is implemented in Startup.cs.

trans-unit.source: This file contains the startup class.
trans-unit.target: This file contains the startup class.

trans-unit.source: The two methods are called by the asp.net core infrastructure to configure and run the application.
trans-unit.target: The two methods are called by the asp.net core infrastructure to configure and run the application.

trans-unit.source: The `ConfigureServices` method describes the services that are necessary for this application.
trans-unit.target: The `ConfigureServices` method describes the services that are necessary for this application.

trans-unit.source: You're building a lean microservice, so it doesn't need to configure any dependencies.
trans-unit.target: You're building a lean microservice, so it doesn't need to configure any dependencies.

trans-unit.source: The `Configure` method configures the handlers for incoming HTTP Requests.
trans-unit.target: The `Configure` method configures the handlers for incoming HTTP Requests.

trans-unit.source: The template generates a simple handler that responds to any request with the text 'Hello World!'.
trans-unit.target: The template generates a simple handler that responds to any request with the text 'Hello World!'.

trans-unit.source: Build a microservice
trans-unit.target: Build a microservice

trans-unit.source: The service you're going to build will deliver weather reports from anywhere around the globe.
trans-unit.target: The service you're going to build will deliver weather reports from anywhere around the globe.

trans-unit.source: In a production application, you'd call some service to retrieve weather data.
trans-unit.target: In a production application, you'd call some service to retrieve weather data.

trans-unit.source: For our sample, we'll generate a random weather forecast.
trans-unit.target: For our sample, we'll generate a random weather forecast.

trans-unit.source: There are a number of tasks you'll need to perform in order to implement our random weather service:
trans-unit.target: There are a number of tasks you'll need to perform in order to implement our random weather service:

trans-unit.source: Parse the incoming request to read the latitude and longitude.
trans-unit.target: Parse the incoming request to read the latitude and longitude.

trans-unit.source: Generate some random forecast data.
trans-unit.target: Generate some random forecast data.

trans-unit.source: Convert that random forecast data from C# objects into JSON packets.
trans-unit.target: Convert that random forecast data from C# objects into JSON packets.

trans-unit.source: Set the response header to indicate that your service sends back JSON.
trans-unit.target: Set the response header to indicate that your service sends back JSON.

trans-unit.source: Write the response.
trans-unit.target: Write the response.

trans-unit.source: The next sections walk you through each of these steps.
trans-unit.target: The next sections walk you through each of these steps.

trans-unit.source: Parsing the Query String.
trans-unit.target: Parsing the Query String.

trans-unit.source: You'll begin by parsing the query string.
trans-unit.target: You'll begin by parsing the query string.

trans-unit.source: The service will accept 'lat' and 'long' arguments on the query string in this form:
trans-unit.target: The service will accept 'lat' and 'long' arguments on the query string in this form:

trans-unit.source: All the changes you need to make are in the lambda expression defined as the argument to `app.Run` in your startup class.
trans-unit.target: All the changes you need to make are in the lambda expression defined as the argument to `app.Run` in your startup class.

trans-unit.source: The argument on the lambda expression is the `HttpContext` for the request.
trans-unit.target: The argument on the lambda expression is the `HttpContext` for the request.

trans-unit.source: One of its properties is the `Request` object.
trans-unit.target: One of its properties is the `Request` object.

trans-unit.source: The `Request` object has a `Query` property that contains a dictionary of all the values on the query string for the request.
trans-unit.target: The `Request` object has a `Query` property that contains a dictionary of all the values on the query string for the request.

trans-unit.source: The first addition is to find the latitude and longitude values:
trans-unit.target: The first addition is to find the latitude and longitude values:

trans-unit.source: The Query dictionary values are `StringValue` type.
trans-unit.target: The Query dictionary values are `StringValue` type.

trans-unit.source: That type can contain a collection of strings.
trans-unit.target: That type can contain a collection of strings.

trans-unit.source: For your weather service, each value is a single string.
trans-unit.target: For your weather service, each value is a single string.

trans-unit.source: That's why there's the call to `FirstOrDefault()` in the code above.
trans-unit.target: That's why there's the call to `FirstOrDefault()` in the code above.

trans-unit.source: Next, you need to convert the strings to doubles.
trans-unit.target: Next, you need to convert the strings to doubles.

trans-unit.source: The method you'll use to convert the string to a double is `double.TryParse()`:
trans-unit.target: The method you'll use to convert the string to a double is `double.TryParse()`:

trans-unit.source: This method leverages C# out parameters to indicate if the input string can be converted to a double.
trans-unit.target: This method leverages C# out parameters to indicate if the input string can be converted to a double.

trans-unit.source: If the string does represent a valid representation for a double, the method returns true, and the `result` argument contains the value.
trans-unit.target: If the string does represent a valid representation for a double, the method returns true, and the `result` argument contains the value.

trans-unit.source: If the string does not represent a valid double, the method returns false.
trans-unit.target: If the string does not represent a valid double, the method returns false.

trans-unit.source: You can adapt that API with the use of an *extension method* that returns a *nullable double*.
trans-unit.target: You can adapt that API with the use of an *extension method* that returns a *nullable double*.

trans-unit.source: A *nullable value type* is a type that represents some value type, and can also hold a missing, or null value.
trans-unit.target: A *nullable value type* is a type that represents some value type, and can also hold a missing, or null value.

trans-unit.source: A nullable type is represented by appending the `?` character to the type declaration.
trans-unit.target: A nullable type is represented by appending the `?` character to the type declaration.

trans-unit.source: Extension methods are methods that are defined as static methods, but by adding the `this` modifier on the first parameter, can be called as though they are members of that class.
trans-unit.target: Extension methods are methods that are defined as static methods, but by adding the `this` modifier on the first parameter, can be called as though they are members of that class.

trans-unit.source: Extension methods may only be defined in static classes.
trans-unit.target: Extension methods may only be defined in static classes.

trans-unit.source: Here's the definition of the class containing the extension method for parse:
trans-unit.target: Here's the definition of the class containing the extension method for parse:

trans-unit.source: The `default(double?)` expression returns the default value for the `double?` type.
trans-unit.target: The `default(double?)` expression returns the default value for the `double?` type.

trans-unit.source: That default value is the null (or missing) value.
trans-unit.target: That default value is the null (or missing) value.

trans-unit.source: You can use this extension method to convert the query string arguments into the double type:
trans-unit.target: You can use this extension method to convert the query string arguments into the double type:

trans-unit.source: To easily test the parsing code, update the response to include the values of the arguments:
trans-unit.target: To easily test the parsing code, update the response to include the values of the arguments:

trans-unit.source: At this point, you can run the web application and see if your parsing code is working.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you can run the web application and see if your parsing code is working.

trans-unit.source: Add values to the web request in a browser, and you should see the updated results.
trans-unit.target: Add values to the web request in a browser, and you should see the updated results.

trans-unit.source: Build a random weather forecast
trans-unit.target: Build a random weather forecast

trans-unit.target: Your next task is to build a random weather forecast.

trans-unit.target: The final code task on the server is to convert the WeatherReport array into a JSON packet, and send that back to the client.

trans-unit.source: Let's start by creating the JSON packet.
trans-unit.target: Let's start by creating the JSON packet.

trans-unit.target: You'll add the NewtonSoft JSON Serializer to the list of dependencies:

trans-unit.target: Then, you can use the `JsonConvert` class to write the object to a string:

trans-unit.target: The code above converts the forecast object (a list of `WeatherForecast` objects) into a JSON packet.

trans-unit.source: After you've constructed the response packet, you set the content type to 'application/json', and write the string.

trans-unit.source: The application now runs and returns random forecasts.
trans-unit.target: The application now runs and returns random forecasts.

trans-unit.source: Load into Docker
trans-unit.target: Load into Docker

trans-unit.source: The Dockerfile created by the asp.net template will serve for our purposes.
trans-unit.target: The Dockerfile created by the asp.net template will serve for our purposes.

trans-unit.source: Let's go over its contents.
trans-unit.target: Let's go over its contents.

trans-unit.source: The first line specifies the source image:
trans-unit.target: The first line specifies the source image:

trans-unit.source: Docker allows you to configure a machine image based on a source template.
trans-unit.target: Docker allows you to configure a machine image based on a source template.

trans-unit.source: That means you don't have to supply all the machine parameters when you start, you only need to supply any changes.
trans-unit.target: That means you don't have to supply all the machine parameters when you start, you only need to supply any changes.

trans-unit.source: The changes here will be to include our application.
trans-unit.target: The changes here will be to include our application.

trans-unit.source: In this first sample, we'll use the `onbuild` version of the RC2 image.
trans-unit.target: In this first sample, we'll use the `onbuild` version of the RC2 image.

trans-unit.target: This is the easiest way to create a working Docker environment.

trans-unit.target: However, the image it creates is larger than necessary.

trans-unit.source: This image include the dotnet core runtime, and the dotnet SDK.
trans-unit.target: This image include the dotnet core runtime, and the dotnet SDK.

trans-unit.source: Conclusion
trans-unit.target: Conclusion

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you built an asp.net core microservice, and added a few features.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you built an asp.net core microservice, and added a few features.

trans-unit.source: You built a docker machine, created an image of your new application and ran that application in the docker vm.
trans-unit.target: You built a docker machine, created an image of your new application and ran that application in the docker vm.

trans-unit.source: Along the way, you saw several features of the C# language in action.
trans-unit.target: Along the way, you saw several features of the C# language in action.
